summary.title: Infosecotb.com with vMeNext Threat Model
summary.description:
Infosecotb.com is a professional cybersecurity blog hosted on WordPress through BlueHost. The blog serves as a platform for sharing insights, articles, and resources related to information security, targeting cybersecurity professionals and enthusiasts.

Website Structure:
•	Content Management System (CMS): Built on WordPress, allowing for easy content creation, management, and publishing.
•	User Interaction: Features such as chatbot, comments, contact forms, and newsletter subscriptions that facilitate user engagement.
•	Categorized Content: Articles are organized into categories based on topics 

Functionality:
•	Article Publishing: Regularly updated with new blog posts that include technical guides, best practices, and industry insights.
•	Search Functionality: Allows users to search for specific topics or articles.
•	Social Media Integration: Links to social media platforms for sharing and promoting content.
•	vMeNext AI powered chatbot

User Types:
•	Visitors: General users seeking information on cybersecurity topics.
•	Administrators: Individuals with backend access for managing content, settings, and website security.

Technical Environment:
•	Hosting: Utilizes BlueHost for hosting, which provides shared or dedicated server resources.
•	Plugins and Themes: Employs various WordPress plugins for enhanced functionality (e.g., SEO, analytics, security).
•	Database: Relies on a MySQL database for storing content, user information, and site settings.
•	vMeNext chatbot published using iFrames

vMeNext is a comprehensive AI-powered chatbot system designed to serve as an intelligent interface for blog content and website management. Built with modern Python technologies, it combines the power of OpenAI's GPT models with automated web scraping, monitoring, and user engagement features.

Key Capabilities:
•	Intelligent Conversations: Powered by OpenAI's latest GPT models for natural, context-aware responses
•	Blog Content Integration: Automatic scraping, processing, and summarization of blog posts
•	Website Monitoring: Continuous availability checking with real-time alerts
•	Document Processing: Support for multiple file formats (PDF, DOCX, TXT, MD)
•	User Engagement: Automated email notifications and contact management
•	Analytics Dashboard: Website uptime statistics with visualizations

data.name: Visitor
data.description: Visitor connecting to infosecotb.com using a browser

data.name:
vMeNext
App
data.description: Gradio ChatBot Python Application with RAG Running on Hugging Face Space

threats.title: Spoofing of iFrame Source
threats.description: The vMeNext App receives an iFrame connection from the infosecotb.com process in the BlueHost Trust Zone, crossing from a different trust boundary. An attacker could spoof the iFrame source to inject malicious content into the chatbot interface.
threats.mitigation: Implement strict Content Security Policy (CSP) in the iFrame embedding and validate the origin of incoming iFrame requests using certificate pinning and origin checks.

threats.title: Information Disclosure via API Responses
threats.description: The vMeNext App processes and responds to API responses from external actors like OpenAI API and SMTP2GO API over public networks with HTTPS encryption. However, if session data or user inputs are inadvertently included in responses, sensitive information could be disclosed due to adjacency to public flows.
threats.mitigation: Sanitize all API responses to remove any user-specific or sensitive data, and implement data masking for logs and outputs. Enforce least privilege in API integrations.

threats.title: Denial of Service from RAG Requests
threats.description: The vMeNext App handles RAG requests to and from the about_me folder store within the Hugging Face Trust Zone. High-volume or malformed requests could overwhelm the local processing, especially since it's a web application adjacent to external API calls.
threats.mitigation: Implement rate limiting on RAG endpoints and resource quotas in the Hugging Face Space to prevent abuse. Use asynchronous processing for file reads.

data.name: about_me folder
data.description: Folder with documents read by Python application and provided to AI ChatBot as a prompt context.

threats.title: Tampering with Stored Documents
threats.description: The about_me folder store holds documents used as prompt context for the vMeNext App within the Hugging Face Trust Zone. As a local store accessible via RAG flows, an attacker with access to the Hugging Face environment could tamper with files, leading to poisoned AI responses.
threats.mitigation: Apply file integrity checks (e.g., hashes) on documents before use in RAG, restrict write access to the folder using Hugging Face permissions, and regularly audit file contents.

threats.title: Information Disclosure of Document Contents
threats.description: The about_me folder store is read by the vMeNext App for RAG processing. If the store is not properly isolated within the trust boundary, contents could be exposed through misconfigured access or adjacency to deployment flows.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt documents at rest and enforce read-only access for the application process. Use Hugging Face's secret management for any sensitive file handling.

threats.title: Elevation of Privilege via Dev Access
threats.description: The DEV actor interacts with the Cursor IDE and vMe Next Dev processes in the Dev/Admin Trust Zone. As a human actor with development privileges, weak access controls could allow elevation to affect production deployments crossing to Hugging Face zone.
threats.mitigation: Enforce role-based access control (RBAC) with multi-factor authentication (MFA) for dev tools, and use separate environments for development and production to prevent privilege escalation.

data.name:
Cursor
IDE
data.description: Cursor IDE used for developing and running vMe Next Dev application and deploying on Hugging Face Space

threats.title: Repudiation in Development Flows
threats.description: The Cursor IDE process handles hosting and deployment flows to Hugging Face API, within the Dev/Admin Trust Zone. Actions like code changes could be repudiated without proper logging, especially with flows to external APIs.
threats.mitigation: Implement comprehensive audit logging for all IDE actions and deployments, including timestamps and user attribution, integrated with a central logging service.

threats.title: Tampering with IDE Code
threats.description: The Cursor IDE process is used for developing the vMeNext application and is adjacent to DEV actor inputs. Malicious code injection or tampering during development could propagate to deployed versions via deployment flows crossing trust boundaries.
threats.mitigation: Use version control with signed commits (e.g., Git with GPG) and automated code scanning in CI/CD pipelines to detect tampering before deployment.

data.name:
infosecotb
.com
data.description: InfoSec Outside The Box Cybersecurity Blog created and managed with WordPress CMS with vMeNext AI powered chatbot added using iFrame

threats.title: Spoofing of Website Requests
threats.description: The infosecotb.com process receives requests from the Visitor actor over public HTTPS flows, crossing into the BlueHost Trust Zone. Attackers could spoof visitor identities to bypass any content restrictions or inject fake requests via the iFrame to vMeNext.
threats.mitigation: Implement client-side certificate authentication or robust session management with CSRF tokens for all user interactions, and validate iFrame sources strictly.

threats.title: Denial of Service on Website
threats.description: The infosecotb.com process, a WordPress web application in the BlueHost Trust Zone, handles public requests and iFrame embeddings. DDoS attacks on ingress flows could overwhelm the shared hosting resources.
threats.mitigation: Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) and DDoS protection services from BlueHost, with rate limiting on all endpoints including the chatbot iFrame.

threats.title: Information Disclosure through WordPress
threats.description: The infosecotb.com process uses WordPress CMS connected to MySQL DB (out-of-scope but adjacent), with public flows. Vulnerable plugins or misconfigurations could disclose admin credentials or user data across the trust boundary.
threats.mitigation: Keep WordPress core, themes, and plugins updated; conduct regular security scans; and use security plugins like Wordfence for intrusion detection and hardening.

threats.title: Tampering with iFrame Flow
threats.description: The iFrame https flow connects the vMeNext App in Hugging Face Trust Zone to infosecotb.com in BlueHost Trust Zone, crossing trust boundaries over a public network with encryption. An attacker could tamper with the embedded content if TLS is not properly validated.
threats.mitigation: Enforce mutual TLS (mTLS) for the iFrame communication and use HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) to prevent downgrade attacks.

threats.title: Information Disclosure in RAG Request
threats.description: The RAG Request flow from vMeNext App to about_me folder store is internal to Hugging Face Trust Zone but involves sensitive document queries. Misconfigured logging could disclose query contents.
threats.mitigation: Disable or anonymize logging for RAG requests and ensure no sensitive data is written to accessible logs.

threats.title: Tampering with RAG Response
threats.description: The RAG Response flow returns document contexts to vMeNext App within the trust zone. If the store is compromised, tampered data could alter AI outputs, affecting user interactions.
threats.mitigation: Validate response integrity with checksums and implement input validation in the app to detect anomalous RAG data.

threats.title: Information Disclosure in SMTP Relay
threats.description: The smtp relay flow from SMTP2GO API to Admin actor crosses public networks with encryption but handles email notifications that may contain user data from vMeNext interactions, risking exposure if intercepted.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt email contents end-to-end and avoid including sensitive user data in notifications; use secure email protocols like SMTPS.

threats.title: Spoofing of Email Sender
threats.description: The smtp relay flow could be spoofed if API keys are compromised, allowing attackers to send fake admin alerts from the SMTP2GO actor.
threats.mitigation: Use DKIM/SPF/DMARC for email authentication and rotate API keys regularly with monitoring for unusual activity.

threats.title: Elevation of Privilege via API Response
threats.description: The API Response flow to vMeNext App from SMTP2GO API crosses public networks. If responses include privilege tokens or escalate based on external data, it could lead to unauthorized access within the app.
threats.mitigation: Strictly validate and sanitize all incoming API responses, implementing least-privilege API scopes and no direct privilege grants from external responses.

threats.title: Tampering with API Request to SMTP2GO
threats.description: The API Request flow from vMeNext App to SMTP2GO API traverses public networks with HTTPS. Without integrity checks, requests could be tampered with to alter email content or recipients.
threats.mitigation: Use message signing for API requests and implement request validation at the API endpoint to ensure integrity.

threats.title: Denial of Service in Admin Response
threats.description: The Admin Response flow from SMTP2GO API to vMe Next Dev process in Dev/Admin zone over public network could be flooded, disrupting admin monitoring.
threats.mitigation: Apply rate limiting and circuit breakers in the admin integration to handle potential DoS from API responses.

threats.title: Repudiation of Admin Interactions
threats.description: The Admin Response flow between SMTP2GO API and vMe Next Dev lacks non-repudiation, allowing denial of admin actions like email sends.
threats.mitigation: Incorporate digital signatures in admin API flows and log all interactions with timestamps for auditability.

threats.title: Information Disclosure in OpenAI API Request
threats.description: The API Request flow from vMe Next Dev to OpenAI API crosses public networks with encryption, but API keys or prompt data could be disclosed if not secured properly.
threats.mitigation: Use API key rotation, environment variables for secrets, and avoid logging sensitive request payloads.

threats.title: Spoofing of OpenAI API Calls
threats.description: The API Request flow from vMeNext App to OpenAI API over public HTTPS could be spoofed if the endpoint is mimicked, leading to data exfiltration via fake API.
threats.mitigation: Implement certificate pinning for OpenAI endpoints and validate API responses against expected schemas.

threats.title: Tampering with OpenAI API Response
threats.description: The API Response flow from OpenAI API to vMeNext App traverses public networks. Tampering could inject malicious AI-generated content into the chatbot.
threats.mitigation: Verify response integrity using HMAC signatures from OpenAI and sanitize outputs before rendering in the app.

data.name: Response
data.description: Response from infosecotb.com website including vMeNext chatbot

threats.title: Information Disclosure in Website Response
threats.description: The Response flow from infosecotb.com to Visitor actor over public HTTPS includes chatbot content from vMeNext iFrame, potentially disclosing sensitive blog or user data if not filtered.
threats.mitigation: Apply data minimization in responses and use secure headers to prevent caching of sensitive content.

data.name: Request
data.description: Request to infosecotb.com website including vMeNext chatbot

threats.title: Elevation of Privilege in WordPress Admin
threats.description: The Admin Response flow from WordPress process to Browser in Dev/Admin zone could allow privilege escalation if weak session management permits unauthorized admin access.
threats.mitigation: Enforce strong password policies, MFA for admin logins, and session timeouts in WordPress.

threats.title: Tampering with Admin Request to WordPress
threats.description: The Admin Request flow from WordPress to Browser crosses into Dev/Admin zone over HTTPS, but could be tampered with to alter content management actions.
threats.mitigation: Use CSRF protection and signed requests for all admin operations in WordPress.

threats.title: Spoofing of BlueHost Admin Requests
threats.description: The Admin Request flow from Browser to BlueHost actor over public networks could be spoofed to gain unauthorized hosting control, affecting the entire BlueHost Trust Zone.
threats.mitigation: Require MFA and IP whitelisting for BlueHost admin access, with anomaly detection on login attempts.

threats.title: Denial of Service from BlueHost Responses
threats.description: The Admin Response flow from BlueHost to Browser could be delayed or flooded, impacting site management in the trust zone.
threats.mitigation: Implement resilient admin interfaces with offline capabilities and monitor for response anomalies.

threats.title: Information Disclosure in Hugging Face Response
threats.description: The Admin Response flow from Hugging Face Host Admin to Browser crosses public networks, potentially exposing deployment secrets or space configurations.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt all admin responses and use short-lived tokens for session management in Hugging Face admin.

threats.title: Tampering with Hugging Face Admin Request
threats.description: The Admin Request flow from Browser to Hugging Face Host Admin over HTTPS could be tampered with to deploy malicious updates to vMeNext App.
threats.mitigation: Sign all deployment requests and use webhooks for verification in Hugging Face integrations.

threats.title: Elevation of Privilege in Deployment Request
threats.description: The Deployment Request flow from Cursor IDE to Hugging Face API crosses from Dev/Admin to Hugging Face zone over public networks, allowing potential privilege escalation if auth is weak.
threats.mitigation: Use scoped API tokens with minimal permissions for deployments and audit all deployment logs.

threats.title: Repudiation of Deployment Actions
threats.description: The Deployment Response flow from Hugging Face API to Cursor IDE lacks strong non-repudiation, enabling denial of deployment changes.
threats.mitigation: Require signed acknowledgments for deployments and integrate with a SIEM for immutable logging.

threats.title: Spoofing in OpenAI Response to Dev
threats.description: The API Response flow from OpenAI API to vMe Next Dev process over public networks could be spoofed, misleading development testing.
threats.mitigation: Validate OpenAI responses with API-specific signatures and use test environments isolated from production.

data.name:
MySQL
DB
data.description: MySQL Database used for WordPress website

threats.title: Denial of Service Targeting Admin
threats.description: The Admin actor receives SMTP relay flows and manages multiple zones (BlueHost, Dev/Admin). Coordinated DoS could prevent oversight of the system.
threats.mitigation: Provide redundant admin access paths and train on incident response for DoS scenarios.

threats.title: Information Disclosure in Dev Process
threats.description: The vMe Next Dev process handles API requests to OpenAI and SMTP2GO within Dev/Admin Trust Zone, adjacent to admin flows. Leaked dev artifacts could expose API keys.
threats.mitigation: Use secret scanning tools in the dev environment and encrypt all local storage.

threats.title: Elevation of Privilege via Browser
threats.description: The Browser process used by Admin actor accesses multiple admin panels (WordPress, BlueHost, Hugging Face) over public flows, risking cross-site scripting (XSS) leading to privilege escalation.
threats.mitigation: Use browser isolation or sandboxing for admin sessions, and enable site isolation features like Chrome's.

data.name:
OpenAI
API
data.description: Artificial Intelligence API secured with a key

threats.title: Denial of Service on OpenAI API
threats.description: The OpenAI API actor receives multiple ingress flows from vMeNext App and vMe Next Dev over public networks, vulnerable to API abuse flooding the service.
threats.mitigation: Configure API rate limits and usage quotas in OpenAI dashboard, monitor for anomalous patterns.

data.name:
SMTP2GO
API
data.description: E-mail relay hosted system API secured with key

threats.title: Tampering with SMTP2GO API
threats.description: The SMTP2GO API actor processes requests from vMeNext App, with flows crossing public networks. Tampering could alter email campaigns or notifications.
threats.mitigation: Enable API request signing and validate all payloads against schemas at the API level.

data.name:
Hugging Face
Host Admin
data.description: Hugging Face Hosting Administrator Control Panel

threats.title: Spoofing of Hugging Face Admin
threats.description: The Hugging Face Host Admin actor handles admin requests from Browser over public HTTPS, susceptible to phishing or spoofed logins affecting space deployments.
threats.mitigation: Enforce MFA and use hardware keys for Hugging Face admin authentication.

threats.title: Elevation of Privilege in Hugging Face API
threats.description: The Hugging Face API actor receives deployment requests from Cursor IDE, crossing zones. Weak token scopes could allow over-privileged deployments.
threats.mitigation: Use fine-grained API permissions and review token scopes regularly for the Spaces API.

threats.title: Information Disclosure from BlueHost
threats.description: The BlueHost actor provides admin responses over public networks, potentially exposing hosting configurations or credentials if logs are queried insecurely.
threats.mitigation: Limit admin query scopes and use encrypted channels for all BlueHost interactions.

threats.title: Repudiation in WordPress Operations
threats.description: The WordPress process manages content and connects to MySQL DB with bidirectional flows in BlueHost zone. Actions like post edits could be repudiated without audit trails.
threats.mitigation: Enable WordPress activity logging plugins and integrate with external audit systems for non-repudiable records.
